con.para: Waves are a way energy moves from one place to another. They carry energy without transporting matter. Waves can travel through various mediums like air, water, and solids, but not all waves need a medium to travel through. There are two main types of waves:

*Mechanical waves* require a medium (like air, water, or solids) to travel. Examples include sound waves and ocean waves. For example, when you throw a pebble into a pond, the ripples that form are mechanical waves that travel through the water.

*Electromagnetic waves* do not require a medium and can travel through a vacuum, like outer space. Light, radio waves, and X-rays are all examples of electromagnetic waves. These waves allow us to see light from the sun, hear radios, and even communicate with satellites.

Waves are described by their properties, including wavelength, frequency, and amplitude. The wavelength is the distance between two consecutive peaks of a wave. Frequency refers to how many waves pass a point in one second. Finally, amplitude measures the height of the wave and determines how much energy it carries.

Light behaves in fascinating ways when it interacts with different surfaces. One way it interacts is through *reflection*, where light bounces off an object. This is how mirrors work—you see your reflection because the light from your face bounces back to your eyes.

*Refraction* is the bending of light as it passes from one medium to another, like from air to water. For example, when you place a straw in a glass of water, it looks bent or broken because the light is bending as it moves through the water.

*Absorption* occurs when light hits an object and is absorbed instead of being reflected or refracted. Dark-colored objects absorb more light, which is why they feel warmer in sunlight. On the other hand, light-colored objects reflect most of the light.

con.title: Light - Colors and the Electromagnetic Spectrum

con.para: Light is part of the *electromagnetic spectrum*, which includes all types of electromagnetic waves.
The *visible spectrum* is the part of the spectrum that humans can see. It consists of the colors of the rainbow—red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, and violet.
Each color of light corresponds to a different wavelength. *Red light* has the longest wavelength, while *violet light* has the shortest.

The electromagnetic spectrum also includes waves we can’t see, like radio waves (used for communication), microwaves (used in cooking), infrared (used in heat detection), ultraviolet (which can cause sunburn), X-rays (used in medical imaging), and gamma rays (used in radiation therapy).
Each type of wave has its own wavelength and energy level.
Sound is a type of *mechanical wave* that travels through a medium like air, water, or solids. Sound waves are created when an object vibrates, causing the particles around it to vibrate as well.
These vibrations travel through the medium and eventually reach our ears, where they are interpreted as sound.

For example, when you pluck a guitar string, the string vibrates, creating sound waves that travel through the air to your ears. In a vacuum, where there is no air or other medium, sound cannot travel, which is why space is silent.
Sound waves move in a pattern of compressions (where particles are close together) and rarefactions (where particles are spread out). These vibrations make sound possible.
Two important characteristics of sound are *pitch* and *volume*.

*Pitch* is how high or low a sound is, and it depends on the frequency of the sound waves. Higher frequency sound waves produce higher-pitched sounds, while lower frequency sound waves create lower-pitched sounds.
For example, a violin produces high-pitched sounds, while a bass guitar produces lower-pitched sounds.

*Volume* refers to how loud or soft a sound is. Volume is determined by the amplitude of the sound wave. A larger amplitude results in a louder sound, while a smaller amplitude creates a softer sound.
Imagine a speaker playing music: turning the volume up increases the amplitude of the sound waves, making the music louder.
